evidence.text: Consistent with Sierra Club v. EPA 551 F. 3d 1019 (D.C. Cir. 2008) and the April 25, 2023, proposal (88 FR 25080), we are revising monitoring and operational requirements for flares to ensure HON and P&R I flares meet the MACT standards at all times when controlling HAP emissions.
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: Sierra Club v. EPA, 551 F. 3d 1019 (D.C. Cir. 2008)

evidence.text: In light of NRDC v. EPA, 749 F.3d 1055 (D.C. Cir., 2014) (vacating affirmative defense provisions in the CAA section 112 rule establishing emission standards for Portland cement kilns), the EPA is also removing, as proposed, all of the regulatory affirmative defense provisions from the P&R I NESHAP at 40 CFR 480(j)(4) in its entirety and all other rule text that references these provisions.
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: NRDC v. EPA, 749 F.3d 1055 (D.C. Cir., 2014)

evidence.text: The commenter also asserted that the EPA's inclusion of infrequent, episodic events in their risk assessment is inappropriate. The commenter explained that short-term or one-time emissions release events are not representative of concentrations an individual would be exposed to over a lifetime. Furthermore, the commenter contended that the EPA should also have excluded EtO emissions related to SSM events from its voluntary risk analysis because the EPA is statutorily obligated to address SSM events under CAA sections 112(d)(2) and (d)(3).
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: Mexichem Specialty Resins, Inc., 787 F.3d. 561 (D.C. Cir. 2015)

evidence.text: The EPA interprets CAA section 112 as not requiring emissions that occur during periods of malfunction to be factored into development of CAA section 112 standards, and this reading has been upheld as reasonable by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in U.S. Sugar Corporation v. EPA, 830 F.3d 579, 606-10 (D.C. Cir. 2016).
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: U.S. Sugar Corporation v. EPA, 830 F.3d 579, 606-10 (D.C. Cir. 2016)

evidence.text: It follows that agency action is lawful only if it rests 'on a consideration of the relevant factors.' State Farm 463 U.S. at 43, (internal quotation marks omitted).
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: State Farm 463 U.S. at 43

evidence.text: Michigan v. EPA, 576 U.S. 743, 750 (2015) (Kagan, J. dissenting) (quoting Industrial Union Dep't v. American Petroleum Institute, 448 U.S. 607, 670 (1980) (Powell, J., concurring in part and concurring in judgment)).
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: Michigan v. EPA, 576 U.S. 743, 750

evidence.text: The Supreme Court pointed out in Entergy Corp. v. Riverkeeper, Inc., 556 U.S. 208, 224 (2009), that the EPA had long determined that it was unreasonable to interpret a statute in a way 'as requiring use of technology whose cost is wholly disproportionate to the environmental benefit to be gained.'
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: Entergy Corp. v. Riverkeeper, Inc., 556 U.S. 208, 224 (2009)

evidence.text: Specifically, the Court vacated the SSM exemptions contained in 40 CFR 63.6(f)(1) and (h)(1), holding that under section 302(k) of the CAA, emissions standards or limitations must be continuous in nature, and that the SSM exemptions violated the CAA's requirement that some CAA section 112 standards apply at all times.
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: Sierra Club v. EPA, 551 F. 3d 1019 (D.C. Cir. 2008) - vacated portions of EPA's CAA section 112 regulations governing emissions of HAP during periods of SSM

evidence.text: In light of NRDC v. EPA, 749 F.3d 1055 (D.C. Cir., 2014) (vacating affirmative defense provisions in the CAA section 112 rule establishing emission standards for Portland cement kilns), the EPA is also removing, as proposed, all of the regulatory affirmative defense provisions from the P&R I NESHAP at 40 CFR 480(j)(4) in its entirety and all other rule text that references these provisions.
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: NRDC v. EPA, 749 F.3d 1055 (D.C. Cir., 2014) - vacated affirmative defense provisions in CAA section 112 rule establishing emission standards for Portland cement kilns

evidence.text: The results of the proposed chronic baseline inhalation cancer risk assessment at proposal indicated that, based on estimates of current actual and allowable emissions, the maximum individual lifetime cancer risk posed by the source category was 2,000-in-1 million driven by EtO emissions from PRDs (74 percent) and equipment leaks (20 percent).
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: EtO emissions from process vents (74% of risk), equipment leaks (20% of risk) from SOCMI source category emissions driving cancer risk

evidence.text: The results of the proposed chronic baseline inhalation cancer risk assessment at proposal indicated that, based on estimates of current actual and allowable emissions, the MIR posed by the source category was 500-in-1 million, driven by chloroprene emissions from maintenance vents (67 percent), storage vessels (11 percent), wastewater (8 percent), and equipment leaks (4 percent).
evidence.source_document: Underlying Decision from Which Petition Arises

add_extracted.value: Chloroprene emissions from maintenance vents (67% of risk), storage vessels (11% of risk), wastewater (8% of risk), and equipment leaks (4% of risk) from Neoprene Production source category emissions driving cancer risk
